articles.headline: Women Were Secretly Filmed at West Point, the Army Says
articles.snippet: The suspect, Sgt. First Class Michael McClendon, sometimes videotaped West Point cadets when they were in the shower, officials said.
articles.abstract: The suspect, Sgt. First Class Michael McClendon, sometimes videotaped West Point cadets when they were in the shower, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A sergeant first class on the staff of the United States Military Academy at West Point has been accused of videotaping female cadets without their consent, sometimes when they were undressed in the bathroom or the shower, according to Army officials.

articles.headline: Despite Risks, Brazil Courts the Millisecond Investor
articles.snippet: The São Paulo stock exchange is trying to accommodate high-speed traders, even as regulators around the world are skeptical of the sector.
articles.abstract: The São Paulo stock exchange is trying to accommodate high-speed traders, even as regulators around the world are skeptical of the sector.
articles.lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — At a time when the mere phrase “high-frequency trading” makes some investors queasy, Brazil’s stock exchange is putting out the digital welcome mat.
articles.byline: By Dan Horch and Nathaniel Popper

articles.headline: Obama, in a Shift, to Limit Targets of Drone Strikes
articles.snippet: A day after admitting the killing of four Americans in drone strikes, the president will announce new limits on the program of targeted attacks. Mr. Obama also plans to renew his effort to close Guantánamo prison.
articles.abstract: A day after admitting the killing of four Americans in drone strikes, the president will announce new limits on the program of targeted attacks. Mr. Obama also plans to renew his effort to close Guantánamo prison.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama plans to open a new phase in the nation’s long struggle with terrorism on Thursday by restricting the use of unmanned drone strikes that have been at the heart of his national security strategy and shifting control of them away from the C.I.A. to the military.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Hackers Find China Is Land of Opportunity
articles.snippet: Hacking in China thrives across official, corporate and criminal worlds and is openly discussed and promoted, whether for breaking into private networks, tracking dissent or stealing trade secrets.
articles.abstract: Hacking in China thrives across official, corporate and criminal worlds and is openly discussed and promoted, whether for breaking into private networks, tracking dissent or stealing trade secrets.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Name a target anywhere in China, an official at a state-owned company boasted recently, and his crack staff will break into that person’s computer, download the contents of the hard drive, record the keystrokes and monitor cellphone communications, too.

articles.headline: In a Plus for Electrics, Tesla Repays a Big Federal Loan Early
articles.snippet: The company, using money it raised last week in the markets, is repaying the government nine years before its loan was due.
articles.abstract: The company, using money it raised last week in the markets, is repaying the government nine years before its loan was due.
articles.lead_paragraph: The taxpayer no longer has to worry about Tesla Motors.

articles.headline: After a Vote, Dimon Moves to Mend Bank’s Fences
articles.snippet: The chief executive of JPMorgan is reaching out to regulators and bolstering the bank’s risk controls.
articles.abstract: The chief executive of JPMorgan is reaching out to regulators and bolstering the bank’s risk controls.
articles.lead_paragraph: A resounding shareholder endorsement of Jamie Dimon has done what JPMorgan Chase’s robust profits and soaring stock price could not: it helps the nation’s largest bank and its chief executive move beyond a multibillion-dollar trading loss that has dogged the bank for more than a year.

articles.headline: Torches and Pitchforks for I.R.S. but Cheers for Apple
articles.snippet: While Wednesday’s I.R.S. hearing felt like an unforgiving, angry inquisition, senators seemed halfhearted in their desire to beat up on Apple, which has been accused of dodging taxes.
articles.abstract: While Wednesday’s I.R.S. hearing felt like an unforgiving, angry inquisition, senators seemed halfhearted in their desire to beat up on Apple, which has been accused of dodging taxes.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One thing became clear this week on Capitol Hill: It is better to be a tax dodger than a tax collector.

articles.headline: U.S. Retailers See Big Risk in Safety Plan for Factories in Bangladesh
articles.snippet: The plan to assure safety in factories, forged after a deadly collapse, could put American retailers at risk for litigation, some specialists say.
articles.abstract: The plan to assure safety in factories, forged after a deadly collapse, could put American retailers at risk for litigation, some specialists say.
articles.lead_paragraph: American retailers remain sharply opposed to joining an international plan to improve safety conditions at garment factories in Bangladesh as their European counterparts and consumer and labor groups dismiss the companies’ concerns about legal liability.

articles.headline: Europe Pushes to Shed Stigma of a Tax Haven
articles.snippet: From Luxembourg to the British Virgin Islands, the authorities are scrambling to  figure out how to change their secretive ways in banking without driving away lucrative foreign clients.
articles.abstract: From Luxembourg to the British Virgin Islands, the authorities are scrambling to  figure out how to change their secretive ways in banking without driving away lucrative foreign clients.
articles.lead_paragraph: LUXEMBOURG — It was a blunt and unsettling message for a country whose opaque banks have sucked in hundreds of billions of euros from abroad and whose national motto — “We want to remain what we are” — is a credo of dogged resistance to change.

articles.headline: Engineers See a Path Out of Green Card Limbo
articles.snippet: Born overseas and educated in the United States, workers in the heart of the tech industry are in a kind of suspension as the Senate considers the immigration bill.
articles.abstract: Born overseas and educated in the United States, workers in the heart of the tech industry are in a kind of suspension as the Senate considers the immigration bill.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Sanket Sant, a citizen of India, came to the United States at age 21, earning a master’s degree in engineering, followed by a doctorate and then landing a well-paying job at a company making semiconductor equipment.

articles.headline: Battle Over ‘GIF’ Pronunciation Erupts
articles.snippet: When the man who invented the GIF, the widely used Web graphic, said that people were pronouncing the term wrong, it started an unexpected debate.
articles.abstract: When the man who invented the GIF, the widely used Web graphic, said that people were pronouncing the term wrong, it started an unexpected debate.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has been called “The Great Schism of the 21st Century” and “The Most Absurd Religious War in Geek History.”

articles.headline: Fed Fears Shake Global Markets but Fade on Wall St.
articles.snippet: Stocks regained ground in New York after global investors were rattled by signs of a slowdown in Chinese manufacturing and a potential easing of central bank support for the economy.
articles.abstract: Stocks regained ground in New York after global investors were rattled by signs of a slowdown in Chinese manufacturing and a potential easing of central bank support for the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investors are contemplating a future without support from one of the biggest engines of the global economy in recent years: the Federal Reserve.
